Literature Review: The landscape of Chapter 11 bankruptcy has undergone significant transformations in recent years, driven by a confluence of factors that have reshaped the dynamics of corporate restructuring. This literature review examines the key trends and their implications for various stakeholders in the bankruptcy process.One of the most notable shifts in Chapter 11 proceedings has been the increasing complexity of prebankruptcy capital structures. Ayotte and Morrison (2009) observed that firms entering bankruptcy now often have multiple layers of secured debt, making negotiations more intricate and potentially contentious. This complexity has contributed to a trend of decreasing time spent in Chapter 11, largely due to the rise of prepackaged (prepack) and prenegotiated bankruptcy plans. Bharath et al. (2014) found that these expedited processes have become increasingly common, allowing companies to emerge from bankruptcy more quickly and with lower costs.The growing use of restructuring support agreements (RSAs) has further accelerated the Chapter 11 process. Baird (2014) noted that RSAs have become a powerful tool for debtors and key creditors to align interests and streamline negotiations before filing for bankruptcy. This trend has been accompanied by an increase in Section 363 sales, where substantially all of a debtor's assets are sold as a going concern. LoPucki and Doherty (2007) documented this shift, highlighting how it has altered the traditional reorganization process and potentially impacted recoveries for various creditor classes.Another significant trend is the increased number of defaulting private equity-owned firms entering Chapter 11. Hotchkiss et al. (2014) examined this phenomenon, finding that private equity-backed companies often enter bankruptcy with higher leverage and more complex capital structures, potentially affecting the outcomes for different stakeholders.The bankruptcy landscape has also been influenced by the growing presence of specialized distressed debt investors. Jiang et al. (2012) studied the role of these investors in Chapter 11 cases, noting their impact on bankruptcy outcomes and their tendency to pursue more aggressive strategies to maximize returns.These trends have collectively shifted the balance of power in Chapter 11 proceedings, often favoring senior secured lenders. Adler et al. (2013) observed that secured creditors have gained significant influence over the bankruptcy process, potentially at the expense of junior creditors and other stakeholders. This shift has also affected out-of-court negotiations, as the threat of a lender-controlled bankruptcy can shape prebankruptcy bargaining dynamics.The impact of these changes on various stakeholders has been a subject of considerable research. For creditors, the effects have been mixed. While senior secured lenders have generally benefited from their increased control, junior creditors may face reduced recoveries. Ivashina et al. (2016) found that recovery rates for unsecured creditors have declined in recent years, particularly in cases involving private equity-owned firms and distressed debt investors.Workers, as key stakeholders in bankruptcy proceedings, have also been affected by these trends. Korobkin (1996) argued that employees often bear a disproportionate burden in corporate restructurings, and recent changes in Chapter 11 dynamics may exacerbate this issue. The emphasis on quick resolutions and asset sales can sometimes prioritize financial restructuring over operational improvements, potentially leading to more job losses or wage concessions.The rise of leveraged loans in corporate finance has further complicated the bankruptcy landscape. Bos et al. (2021) examined the growth of the leveraged loan market and its implications for corporate defaults and restructurings. They found that the prevalence of covenant-lite loans and the changing nature of creditor rights have altered the dynamics of financial distress and bankruptcy negotiations.In conclusion, the changing face of Chapter 11 bankruptcy reflects broader shifts in corporate finance, creditor rights, and investment strategies. While these changes have led to more efficient resolutions in some cases, they have also raised concerns about the balance of power among stakeholders and the long-term implications for corporate governance and financial stability. As the bankruptcy landscape continues to evolve, ongoing research will be crucial to understanding and addressing these complex issues.
